text: On tap. Pours a clear brick red with a frothy off-white head and light carbonation. Aromas are fairly light though caramel, flowers and raisins come through. Taste is much the same though lifted by a fruity hop note in the mid-palate. Wouldnt have picked it as low a.b.v. Could easily pass as a regular red/amber. A little one-dimensional but very easy drinking. Quite liked it.
On tap at kilsyth club no real aroma deep amber in colour big off white head taste is bitter but it just lacks something possibly due to the low abv
Hop herbal spice aroma. Murky Amber colour great head and lacing. Malt herbal floral spice flavour. Smooth lingering palate.

on tap at the hop factory in newcastle. amber with a lasting white head; aroma of pond scum, coola cordial, honeycomb and old dark well; curious honey rye flavour with a steady earthy hop finish. curious and pretty good for a light beer
Fresh, seabreeze hop aroma w tropical fruit. A little fizzy, fruity and fairly bitter. Ok.

Draught as part of a tasting paddle at Rubber Duckie Taphouse, Sydney, on July 14, 2013.Described as an "IPA".A little bit hazy deep golden color, off-white head. Fruity, hoppy, dry wall, malty, mineral, bitter taste. Mineral, dry wall, bitter aftertaste, also grapefruit. Medium to fizzy mouthfeel, medium to medium high dry bitterness. Sweet, hoppy, fruity scent.

On tap at Murray's Manly. Bright copper, grassy hop aroma, light bodied but really flavorsome beer, a standout light. Wish they bottled this stuff - liquid gold!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
(On tap) Clear copper colour with slight white head. Floral hop aroma. Good carbonation. Caramel and hoppy bitterness taste. An excellent light beer.

Draught
Wow, now this is something completely out there!
Amber sort of beer, rocky head holds on.
Hop aroma is just HUGE, almost go as far as to call it more intense than the Icon; resiny, ripe fruits, pine, woody spice, pepper, and not to outplayed, theres still a good punch of toffee and nutty malt underneath.
Body is really where this beer is astounding; unbelievably full bodied, chewy malt texture, with decent length. Youd swear the beer was at least twice the abv!
Once again, I really cant help but think of the Icon when sipping it, the hop character is off the chart, so resiny almost sticky, malt drops away maybe a bit quicker than the Icon, but bitterness is just as high lingering unabated for an eternity, somewhat aggressivel so.
Very special beer, almost too intense to be considered a sessionable beer, but at light beer strength you certainly could have a big session on it...and probaby wreek of hops for a week...
On tap at Local Taphouse Sydney. Not sure if this is an American Pale Ale but it does have a lot of flavour for a very low alcohol beer.  Solid copper colour this is not bad.
Draught at The Local Taphouse in St Kilda (Melbourne). Difficult to get these beers right when playing around the margins. This just doesnt quite get there, the body just being too thin.

(on tap at Taphouse Syd) Pale ale or some take on an English ale? Mild style and perhaps low ABV. Light caramel malts and some low impact herbal hops. Theres a slight rusty mineral touch nods to an IPA but to be truthful I cant reall pick the style. (later learnt of the the 2.8% so in this context a stunning low abv beer)

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 Tap. Quite a full hoppy nose. In the mouth it is reminisant of tea with a slightly muddled hoppy finish. I think this would be sharper and more impressive when it was first released, not a month down the track. Enjoyable.
